Award.AwardTitle: Smart Start to Skilled Technical Careers in Energy Management Technology
Award.AbstractNarration:
The future of energy use is changing as smart technologies integrate with traditional mechanical systems to control lighting, ventilation, security, and other functions in residential and industrial buildings. For example, modern building controls now include devices such as Wi-Fi enabled lighting controls with daylight sensors, carbon-dioxide sensors to control ventilation rates, and power load alarms for critical needs like food refrigeration. As a result, the need for skilled energy technicians has grown and the skills they need are more complex. In Northeast Wisconsin, the demand for energy management technicians continues to exceed the supply of qualified applicants. Thus, new strategies are needed to address shortages and create a workforce of skilled technicians to manage these technologies. In this project, Northeast Wisconsin Technical College will partner with local employers to increase the number of skilled energy management technicians. Specifically, the project intends to develop an energy management educational program that bridges mechanical equipment engineering skills with information technology and computational skills. The program will be designed to prepare a skilled technical workforce that will address energy management needs in an increasingly internet-connected, global society.

Faculty in the existing Energy Management Technology program and the College’s K-12 relations manager will collaborate with industry and secondary education representatives to educate students, instructors, and educational leaders about today’s smart technology-driven building control systems. Through this partnership, the project plans to: create an Energy Controls Career Pathway Certificate as an entry-level pathway credential; increase energy career and education awareness, with attention to recruiting more women to a field traditionally dominated by men; provide curriculum, hands-on resources, training, and supports for high school instructors to deliver a one-credit course in the Certificate; and launch the full Certificate as an entry-level credential through dual credit delivery for high school juniors and seniors. This project has the potential to create a replicable model for meeting employer demand for skilled technicians. Ultimately, it is anticipated that the project will support reductions in the cost of smart energy installations and maintenance, benefiting the environment, as well as consumer health and finances. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Smart Start to Skilled Technical Careers in Energy Management Technology project collaborated with industry and secondary education to introduce more high school students to a career in building controls through entry-level credentials. Project objectives included: 1) Create Energy Controls Career Pathway Certificate, 2) Increase energy career awareness and educational opportunities to support expanded pipeline of students, 3) Support high school instructor delivery of one-credit Smart Start to BAS course, and 4) Launch full Energy Controls Certificate as an entry-level pathway credential for energy technicians. The Smart Start project’s disciplinary focus of energy management education incorporated conducting a needs assessment, educational materials development, professional development for secondary instructors, industry and career exploration, and delivery of Energy Controls Career Pathway Certificate content with student and instructor supports to expose students, instructors, and educational leaders to an energy world today driven by smart technology. The project impacted more than 75 high school staff members and 2,000 pre-college students who attended outreach events, eight pre-college teachers and twenty-three pre-college students taking dual credit courses, three college career staff who provided post-secondary guidance, and more than 100 industry and organizational partners who received communications about the project.

Intellectual Merit. The future of energy is changing, and building professionals are at the nexus of this shift as smart technologies integrate with traditional mechanical systems. Building controls is an inherently interdisciplinary concept that covers multiple occupations and related technological programs. Building controls workforce demand exceeds the supply of qualified technicians. New strategies are needed to address shortages and create a workforce of skilled technicians. The Smart Start project bridged mechanical equipment engineering skills with IT and computer management skills, beginning at the secondary level, to imbue a workforce with the tools needed to address energy management concerns in an increasingly internet-connected global society.

Broader Impacts. Clean energy jobs are growing at a rapid pace as the nation continues to embrace renewable energy sources. The Smart Start project sought to create a pipeline of future skilled Energy Technicians to support employer demand, ultimately reducing the cost of renewable energy installations and helping consumers save energy, thereby benefiting the environment and consumer health and pocketbooks. NWTC built off past successes in working with the high school population to explore increased post-secondary enrollment. The project outreach impacted first-generation students in communities where traditionally 30% or greater of the high school graduates do not pursue post-secondary education. The Smart Start project utilized a variety of platforms for dissemination of lesson plans, assessments, hands-on activities, and best practices. Project outreach to secondary school stakeholders and middle and high school students created interest in energy careers. While the interest did not immediately translate into large volumes of course enrollment or career pathway progression, it generated interest in further adaptation of curriculum for learning about energy controls across the building and energy-related fields. The controls industry is global; the skills gaps experienced by NWTC’s district employers are not unique to Northeast Wisconsin. The Smart Start project documentated use of open protocol and affordable controllers to allow for replicated used of the hands-on trainer at other colleges across the country.
